poem:
Title: Vote and Verse

Split world, cracked like terracotta,
two spheres dance to Gaza's tune.
Midwestern plains drowned in echoes,
and distant drum rolls under English moon.
Democracy and chaos, wearing the same tie,
An uncommitted vote, a hesitant sigh.
In the ballot's ballet, Biden might stumble,
Will the Gaza puzzle make giants tumble?
Tune in tomorrow: a sequel, a repeat,
Endlessly spinning, this song we bleat.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Thursday briefing: Could the ‘uncommitted vote’ over Gaza cost Joe Biden at the polls? Good morning. Over the next two newsletters I’ll look at very two different elections that are thousands of miles apart but similarly fractured by the war in Gaza. Today we will be in a midwestern state in the US, and tomorrow we’ll be in a small town in the north of England. Stay tuned. Normally, an uncontested Democratic primary race with". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
